etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Richard Saunders. From post-classical Latin peiorat-, past participial stem of peiorare to make worse (late 2nd or early 3rd century a.d.) from classical Latin pēior worse (functioning as the comparative of malus bad: see mal-) from the same Indo-European base as foot [interjection]; compare -ior

definitions: To make worse; to cause to deteriorate. In later use also: to endow (a word) with a less favourable meaning.
